title: BASF works to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2050 - CosmeticsDesign.com USA
summary: BASF is a chemical manufacturer that has taken a leading role in managing carbon emissions throughout the company and is diligently working to better adhere to the principles of environmental sustainability. BASF recognizes its responsibility for climate protection and has committed to further reducing emissions from its production processes. To achieve its goals, the company has set some ambitious quantitative objectives to measure progress, including the use of new technologies to replace fossil fuels with electricity from renewable sources, and the development of a digital application tool to calculate the cradle-to-gate PCFs (Product Carbon Footprints) for its 45,000 sales products.
green_innovation: TRUE, the article describes the development of a digital tool to calculate the cradle-to-gate PCFs (Product Carbon Footprints) for BASF's sales products, which enables the company to provide PCFs for its global portfolio.
business_innovation: TRUE, the article describes the development of a digital tool to calculate the cradle-to-gate PCFs (Product Carbon Footprints) for BASF's sales products, which is a new or improved business process for one or more business functions that differs significantly from the firm’s previous business processes.
green_product: FALSE, the article does not describe a green product.
green_process: TRUE, the article describes the development of a digital tool to calculate the cradle-to-gate PCFs (Product Carbon Footprints) for BASF's sales products, which is a new or improved business process for one or more business functions that differs significantly from the firm’s previous business processes and aims to reduce the overall carbon footprint.
product_or_process: digital application tool to calculate the cradle-to-gate PCFs (Product Carbon Footprints)
likely_naics_codes: ['325199 All Other Basic Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing', '325211 Plastics Material and Resin Manufacturing', '325991 Custom Compounding of Purchased Resins', '325998 All Other Miscellaneous Chemical Product and Preparation Manufacturing']
greenwashing: FALSE, the article does not describe a process innovation that is an example of greenwashing.

title: Where Is Oregon's Seafood? – Oregon Business - Oregon Business
summary: OCVA reports on local seafood availability to consumers along the Oregon Coast, including ways of increasing local product sales; Innovative seafood infrastructure systems like the Yaquina Lab are being implemented to help keep seafood local to Oregon communities with economic benefits of $90 million annually; OCVA seeks to reestablish local supply chains to increase access to healthy, environmentally friendly seafood options for both residents and visitors.
green_innovation: TRUE - OCVA's focus on developing hyperlocal seafood infrastructure and distribution systems, along with increased support for innovation in seafood products and processes, is considered green innovation due to its aim to reduce environmental impacts within the seafood industry
business_innovation: TRUE - OCVA's efforts to establish small-scale seafood processing, storage and distribution infrastructure, as well as its support for innovation in seafood products and processes, are examples of business innovations aimed at improving the efficiency and sustainability of the seafood industry.
green_product: TRUE - The seafood products highlighted in the article are considered green products because they are locally sourced, sustainably caught, and processed in a way that minimizes environmental impact.
green_process: TRUE - The seafood processing and distribution systems implemented by OCVA are considered green processes because they prioritize sustainability, reduce waste, and promote the use of environmentally friendly practices.
product_or_process: hyperlocal seafood infrastructure and distribution systems
likely_naics_codes: ['114111 - Finfish Fishing', '492110 - Couriers', '484220 - Seafood Product Preparation and Packaging', '311812 - Commercial Bakeries']
greenwashing: FALSE - The article does not provide any evidence of greenwashing in the seafood industry.
